speaker: Skyline
text: An orange sun rises over the city, and as it does, it becomes a Jack-O-Lantern.  This season's color for the "Frasier" title is happily appropriate for this episode!_]   [_Scene 1 - Frasier's Apartment. Daphne enters from the kitchen.  Frasier enters, wearing his Halloween costume.  He has gray hair, a gray beard, and is wearing a nineteenth-century suit.  Clearly he is meant to be Sigmund Freud._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Wow, look at you!  You look just...[_at a loss_] like him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Daphne, come on! [_indicating costume_] Huh?  The theme this evening is to come dressed as your hero. [_He places a cigar in his mouth._]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_guessing_] Fidel Castro!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_irritated_] Sigmund Freud!  [_Daphne picks up a bowl of candy._] Daphne, don't you think that bowl is a little bit small for a whole night of trick-or-treaters?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I don't think so.  The children in the building are too scared to ring our bell.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why is that?

speaker: Daphne
text: They're afraid of "Old Man Crane."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_chuckling_] Poor Dad.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's not him, Dr. Crane, it's you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taken aback_] What?!  I'm Old Man Crane?  Good Lord, I have tousled every young head in this building from the laundry room to the rooftop.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, apparently that's how it started.  They think you're feeling to see if their brains are ripe.

speaker: Frasier
text: How do you know all this?

speaker: Daphne
text: They have a whole rhyme about you. [_singing_] "Old Man Crane, Old Man Crane, Make him mad and he'll eat your brain."

speaker: Frasier
text: That's absurd.  How do children get such crazy ideas?  [_Cut to the hall outside the apartment.  Six costumed children are loudly chasing each other with toy ray guns.  Martin and Eddie emerge from the elevator._]

speaker: Martin
text: Whoa! Hey, hey, keep it down, will 'ya?

speaker: Boy
text: We're just playing.

speaker: Martin
text: I know, but...you know how "Old Man Crane" gets.  Especially on Halloween, or as he calls it, "Harvest Time."  [_The children run screaming down the hall.  Martin chuckles.  Fade Out._]   **It's Flu and Party Season**  [_Scene 2 - Frasier's apartment. Martin enters, dressed in a New York Yankees uniform and carrying a bat. Frasier is seated at the table, preparing his Halloween game._]

speaker: Martin
text: [_indicating costume and smiling broadly_] Fras...?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_at a loss_] Hello...baseball man.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on! Joe DiMaggio [_he turns to reveal the number 5_]. You know who he is, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course. Joe DiMaggio was married to Marilyn Monroe... who was also married to Arthur Miller, the playwright who wrote you see, Dad, I know a lot more about baseball than you think.

speaker: Martin
text: How does this party game of yours work?  Is it like Charades? 'Cause I don't like Charades.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, no Dad.  It's actually much better.  You see, I've devised some questions that we will answer _as_ our heroes. What better way to learn about each other than to explore the personalities of those who most inspire us, huh? [_chuckles_]

speaker: Martin
text: Couldn't we just play Charades?  [_Frasier moves to the coffee table with the game questions in a bowl. Martin moves to his chair._]

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, if this evening goes really well, I may consider marketing my little invention.  It's a welcome change from those tiresome theme parties where someone gets murdered.

speaker: Martin
text: [_drily_] It could still happen.  [_Phone rings.  Frasier answers._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello?  Gil.  Good heavens, shouldn't you be on your way by now?...Well, yes, of course we'll be playing my little game. Oh.  You don't sound sick...Oh, now I hear it.  Oh, all right, feel better [_hangs up_].

speaker: Martin
text: Isn't that like your eighth cancellation?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes. There must be something going around at the office.  [_The doorbell rings.  Frasier opens it to reveal Roz and Alice, who is dressed as a puppy._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi!

speaker: Roz
text: [_noticing Martin_] Hey, it's Joe DiMaggio!

speaker: Martin
text: [_tipping his cap_] Ma'am.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see you've brought a little puppy.

speaker: Roz
text: Yes, we've been trick-or-treating all afternoon and she's exhausted.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's strange.  The children in our building haven't even started trick-or-treating.

speaker: Roz
text: Are you kidding?  I just rode up the elevator with five Britney Spears and a sweaty Harry Potter.  I'm going to go put her down in your room.  Can I change there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as you know, Roz [_assuming an Austro-German accent_], change can only occur after years of hard work _und_ analysis. [_He places the cigar in his mouth._]

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Martin_] It's going to be a hell of a party.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  [_Daphne enters, wearing very loud blue pants and jacket, which are covered with silver musical eighth notes.  Her shirt is yellow with a huge collar, and she is wearing a bowler hat in the same loud shade of blue over a wig with large sideburns.  Last, but not least, she sports a pair of glasses with very large, thick frames._]

speaker: Martin
text: What the heck are you supposed to be?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_delighted_] Reginald Dwight.  You might know me as Sir Elton John.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, I must say, I hardly think of Elton John as an heroic figure.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_defensive_] Yes, he is!  He's been a great musician for over thirty years.  There's also his charity work and his knighthood!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I must say I never thought about it that way, which is exactly the point of this evening.  Thank you for putting so much thought into your costume rather than just throwing on something frivolous.  [_Daphne is pleased at having vindicated her costume.  At this point, Roz enters in a _complete_ Wonder Woman costume with full black wig._]

speaker: Roz
text: Ta-Da! [_She twirls her cape, poses proudly, and smiles broadly._]

speaker: Martin
text: Wow, Roz, you look great!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_annoyed_] Oh, Roz, are you serious?

speaker: Roz
text: [_taken aback_] What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Your hero is Wonder Woman?  You're supposed to come dressed as the person you most admire, whom you most wish to emulate.  I'm not even sure you can do that to the flag!

speaker: Roz
text: [_clearly hurt_] I'm sorry.  When you said "hero" I thought you meant "superhero."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and when you saw me dressed in a beard with a cigar, what "superhero" did you think I was, hmm?

speaker: Roz
text: That butler who cooked for Batman?

speaker: Daphne
text: Speaking of which, would you help me bring out some cheese, Wonder Woman?

speaker: Roz
text: [_in her "heroic" pose_] I'd be glad to, Elton John!  [_The phone rings.  Frasier answers._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello?  Kenny...Gosh, don't you think you should have left by now?...Well, actually, you know, there have been a few cancellations, so that will allow us to delve even deeper into our psyches... [_Martin looks concerned, knowing what is about to happen._] Really, what kind of sick?...[_credulous_] Oh, gosh, that sounds horrible...Yes, all right, well, um, take care [_hangs up_].  You know, we might be wise to take some echinacea.  [_The doorbell rings.  Frasier answers to reveal Niles, who is clearly dressed as his father.  He wears a gray wig, a flannel shirt, khaki pants with a belt, and he carries a cane and a stuffed Jack Russell terrier._]

speaker: Niles
text: [_imitating Martin_] Somebody get me a beer!  [_Martin is delighted.  Frasier is not._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  What in the world?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you said dress as your hero.  Hello, Dad!  [_Martin rises and moves toward Niles._]

speaker: Martin
text: Holy Moly!  Niles, this is unbelievable!

speaker: Niles
text: You like it?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I love it! [_embraces Niles_]  But Frasier said to dress as your hero, not as the handsomest man in the world!  [_They simultaneously execute the characteristic "Martin" laugh: a single "Ha!" followed by a backward-leaning gesture.  They laugh hysterically and pat each other on the back.  Frasier walks away, unamused._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I thought you were going to come as Carl Jung!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I changed my mind!

speaker: Frasier
text: But the idea of this evening is to come as a classic hero, someone who truly inspires you.  No offense, Dad.  You know, someone of truly unquestioned greatness!  Again, no offense, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: [_irritated_] Blow it out your whistle.  No offense.  [_Roz and Daphne enter from the kitchen.  Roz carries a food plate, Daphne two filled wine glasses.  Both are delighted with Niles's costume._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, my goodness!

speaker: Roz
text: Ohh, isn't that the cutest thing?

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Daphne_] What the heck are you supposed to be?

speaker: Martin
text: That's exactly what I said!  [_Again, they simultaneously do the "Martin" laugh and lean backwards at the same time.  Niles moves to embrace and kiss Daphne._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I guess we have a full complement.  We may as well get on to the main event.  Wonder Woman, Elton John, Martin Crane, Joe DiMaggio--I think you all know each other.  Why don't you have a seat and we will proceed to a night of frivolity and enlightenment.  [_Niles and Martin both move to the barcalounger._]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Joe, I insist you take my chair.

speaker: Martin
text: Thanks, Marty! [_Niles takes a chair from the table._]

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, then, let's dive into the question bowl.  Now remember, our job is to answer these questions as the people we honor tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, what if I'm someone who just wants to watch TV.  Can I do that? [_He reclines and places his feet on an ottoman._]

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, can he?

speaker: Frasier
text: Very amusing.  Oh, yes, yes, I took the liberty of jotting down a few reminders and regulations for your edification. [_He begins to hand out sheets of paper._]

speaker: Martin
text: [_handing Niles a beer_] Here you go, Marty!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, uh,...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, you don't really have to drink that.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm already wearing black shoes with white socks.  I may as well go all the way. [_He sips the beer.  Martin laughs._]

speaker: Frasier
text: All right. Question number one. [_taking a slip of paper from the bowl_]  The inaugural question in the first game ever of "Hero Worship."  Copyright Frasier Crane, boilerplate, boilerplate. [_reading from the paper_] "As your hero, please share your reaction to the human genome project, not only as a scientific venture, but as a regulatory challenge to governments--foreign and domestic."

speaker: Martin
text: No.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you insane?  [_Roz and Daphne also express irritation._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_putting the paper down_] Oh, all right, all right.  Maybe we'll just save that for the lightning round. [_He takes another paper from the bowl._] Well...as your hero [_reading_] "describe the most significant relationship in your life."  [_They find this more agreeable._]

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll tell you what.  I'll go first. [_assuming Austrian accent and posing as Freud._] So it is common for a parent to deeply impact the life of her child.  Consider the exponential power that parent wields when she loves one of the children above the rest, singling him out as "My golden Sigi," and referring to him...  [_Niles and Martin simultaneously interrupt him with "Boring!" and begin to laugh hysterically.  Frasier is unamused._]

speaker: Roz
text: Really, Frasier, mother-Freud.  We get it.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, very well.  Now, in the first of many wrinkles, the game will proceed _counterclockwise._  Joe.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, all right.  Well, even though I had a big family, I'd have to say that my most important relationship was probably with Marilyn Monroe...although I might have been married before that, I'm not sure.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_in a bad Elton John imitation_] I wrote a song about Marilyn Monroe: "Candle in the Wind."  [_They all stare bemused at "Elton John."_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, that's very good.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but Wonder Woman, you're next.

speaker: Roz
text: OK, my...greatest relationship was with my alter ego, who was a nurse in the army and her name was Diana Prince.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_same bad Elton John accent_] Hey!  I wrote a song about Princess Diana...and it was the same song I wrote about Marilyn Monroe!

speaker: Roz
text: That's weird!

speaker: Martin
text: Really weird!

speaker: Niles
text: You would never think that two such disparate characters across half a century of time could be connected like that.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_very annoyed_] That's because they're not connected!  The song was written about Princess Diana, not Diana Prince!

speaker: Daphne
text: Still, it's a pretty odd coincidence...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_cutting her off_] It's not a coincidence at all!  It's just two names that barely sound alike when one of them is pronounced in reverse order!  Now, if we could just return to my game...

speaker: Roz
text: It says right here that one of the objectives is "lively conversation."

speaker: Martin
text: Which is what we're having.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think I know what my game's objectives are, and they do not include this nascent migraine!  All right, Martin Crane.  Why don't you tell us about your most significant relationship.

speaker: Niles
text: All righty.  In 1952, I met a woman named Hester Palmer.  And even thought she's been gone fourteen years, she was not only the greatest relationship in my life but also the greatest blessing.  I miss her every day.

speaker: Martin
text: [_touched_] You're a good boy, Niles.  [_Daphne and Roz share in the warm, sweet admiration of Niles's speech. Frasier does not._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, could I see you in the kitchen? [_He walks to the kitchen alone._]

speaker: Niles
text: Did Niles finally get here?  Where is that boy genius?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's okay!  Dad, can I see you in the kitchen please?

speaker: Niles
text: Why is he looking at me?  I'm not Freud's "Dad."

speaker: Frasier
text: [_highly irritated_] Martin Crane!!  [_Niles finally rises and heads to the kitchen, limping Martin-like on his cane._]

speaker: Frasier
text: It doesn't take Freud to see what's going on here.

speaker: Niles
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, your little ploy is working out brilliantly, isn't it?  Not only have you stolen my thunder as host, you have also won the approval you so desperately crave from Dad.  [_Niles has taken another beer from the refrigerator._]

speaker: Niles
text: This is not about craving approval.  This is about honoring someone I respect and admire.  The fact that you're threatened by it speaks volumes about your insecurity. [_He begins to drink the beer.  Frasier grabs him._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't you turn this on me!  I am perfectly comfortable in my relationship with Dad.

speaker: Niles
text: Then you should be glad that he's having fun.  It rarely happens at your parties...or mine.  So why don't we both take pride in that and just be happy for him?  Or, as Dad would say: "Shut your big bazoo and stop thinkin' so much!" [_He does the "Martin" laugh and leans backwards, then exits the kitchen._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Let's play "Scattergories!"

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, do you have one of those murder mystery games?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_emerging from the kitchen_] So that's it, then?  The party's over?

speaker: Martin
text: What are you talking about? We're just getting started.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're not playing my game.  This is chaos.  We're just five people in costumes drinking.

speaker: Martin
text: Amen!  [_handing Roz a camera_] Here, Roz, would you take a picture of Marty Crane with his hero, Joe DiMaggio?  [_Martin and Niles pose near Martin's chair.  Roz snaps the picture._]

speaker: Martin
text: That'll make a great Christmas card.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_moving to the coat rack_] Yeah, good idea, Dad. You've already ruined Halloween, why not ruin Christmas too? [_He heads for the front door._]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Frasier, come on, relax.  We're just having fun. Hey, have a beer.  It really takes the edge off.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, don't be a spoilsport!

speaker: Frasier
text: Spoilsport?  I haven't spoiled anything.  I'm not the bad guy here.  [_A group of costumed children is at the door as Frasier exits.  They scream in horror and run away.  Frasier leaves and the rest of them stand in the living room wondering what to make of his behavior. Fade out._]     [_Scene 3 - Elliot Bay Towers Lobby Four costumed kids are outside the elevator.  Two are struggling over a bag of candy.  The larger of the two wins.  All of the kids except the one whose candy was stolen run off.  Frasier emerges from the elevator. The kid, Justin, is wearing a cowboy costume and looks about ten years old._]

speaker: Justin
text: Hey, that's mine!

speaker: Frasier
text: Did that boy just steal your candy?

speaker: Justin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Tell me his name.  I'll go speak to his parents for you.

speaker: Justin
text: His parents are my parents.  He's my brother. [_sits on a bench_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, it isn't easy having a brother, is it?

speaker: Justin
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: They can be selfish and thoughtless.

speaker: Justin
text: And butt-faces.

speaker: Frasier
text: Butt-faces, yes.  And butt-faces, too. [_Joins Justin on the bench_] But you know what might put things right?

speaker: Justin
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: The smallest pinch of fiberglass in his bed.  It'll get under his skin.  It'll itch for days with no clue how it got there. Have you seen those spare rolls of insulation they keep in the basement?

speaker: Justin
text: That sounds pretty mean.

speaker: Frasier
text: He stole your candy, didn't he?  And embarassed you in front of your friends.

speaker: Justin
text: I guess.  But still he's not so bad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Seemed pretty bad a moment ago.

speaker: Justin
text: Well, he was just showing off.  But most days he's all right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Still, the man stole your candy.  And ruined your much- anticipated evening. [_Frasier is now clearly talking about himself._]  Shouldn't there be repercussions?

speaker: Justin
text: Are you okay?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  I suppose I'm just having a bit of a temper tantrum, that's all.

speaker: Justin
text: Yeah, I get those too. [_Frasier chuckles._] Well, I'm going home.  See you later. [_He heads to the elevator._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yup, see you later.  Say, you know, maybe I'll go home too. [_He rises to join Justin at the elevator._]  If your brother doesn't give back your candy, you can always come trick-or- treating at my apartment.  I got bags of the stuff.  You can have all you want.

speaker: Justin
text: Really? Awesome! [_They enter the elevator._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Apartment 1901.

speaker: Justin
text: [_suddenly fearful_] 1901? [_The elevator door closes on his troubled face.  Cut to interior of elevator._] You're the guy who eats brains.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, come on.  If I really ate brains, children would be disappearing from the building all the time.  You haven't noticed anything like that, have you?

speaker: Justin
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's because I don't eat brains. [_musing_] Not human brains, anyway. [_Justin is startled._] A nice fresh order of calf's brains in a beurre noir sauce, now that would be...[_seeing Justin's uneasiness_] I don't eat brains.  [_Fade out._]  [_Scene 4 - Frasier's apartment. Martin emerges from the kitchen to witness an amorous display between Niles and Daphne.  Roz is also there._]

speaker: Martin
text: All right, stop it.

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: I don't want to watch myself make out with Elton John.  [_Frasier enters._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, all.

speaker: All
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: I would like to apologize for my petulant departure.  I just want us all to enjoy ourselves this evening.  And Niles, I never should have questioned your motives for this wonderful tribute.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you son. [_He belches.  He is drinking yet another beer and is clearly beginning to show the effects.  We see that there are about six empty cans on the TV tray._]

speaker: Daphne
text: It was our fault too, Dr. Crane.  We really didn't give your game a chance.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, let's give it another shot! [_placing baseball cap on his head_] Joltin' Joe wouldn't quit, and neither will I.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Roz, since you misunderstood tonight's theme, tell you what, why don't you answer this question as your true hero, whomever that may be.

speaker: Roz
text: Actually, I didn't misunderstand anything.  You made so much fun of my costume, I got so embarassed, so I lied.  Wonder Woman really is my hero.  I mean, she's smart and beautiful, moral, and totally independent.

speaker: Niles
text: [_increasingly inebriated_] And talk about hooters!

speaker: Martin
text: [_slightly irritated_] Hey, I keep that to myself.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I never should have criticized you. I am terribly sorry. [_to Daphne, who is handing him a wine glass_] Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Daphne, you didn't bring me a brewster.

speaker: Martin
text: I think you've had enough.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you can never have enough beer, Jodi.

speaker: Martin
text: That's _Joe D._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I believe that you're next.

speaker: Niles
text: Huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Tell us about your hero's greatest disappointment.  [_Niles is now very drunk.  Everybody becomes increasingly uneasy during his next speeches.  He is now standing and leaning on the cane._]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, um, that I never got to take my kids to see Joe DiMaggio play.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's not your fault, Marty, I retired when they were infants.

speaker: Niles
text: Guess it's not that important.  My kids wouldn't know a baseball if it hit them in the face.  In fact, that pretty much describes their one day in Little League. [_imitating Martin's characteristic chuckle_] No offense, Joe, my kids did not care about baseball.  Hell, they didn't care about anything that was important to me.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, now that's not fair.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, no, no, no, I'm just saying that you and me, we're regular guys.  You know, we know how to hang out with regular guys and shoot the breeze and, and, and knock a few back.  But, uh, not my kids.  No, they're too good for that stuff. [_Frasier and Daphne have concerned looks on their faces._]  They got all their fancy degrees, but they never learned how to be regular guys. [_Martin looks very hurt and angry._]  So I guess if I had to pick my two biggest disappointments...

speaker: Martin
text: [_angrily_] You stop right there! [_rises, confronting Niles_] You will not put these words in my mouth.  I was always proud of you boys, and I will not be portrayed as some drunken, judgmental jackass!  [_Martin leaves the room.  Niles seems shocked at his own behavior and the reaction it has elicited._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_grasping_] That's why I didn't dress as you, Dad!

speaker: Martin
text: [_sincerely, while exiting_] You're a good son, Frasier.

speaker: Roz
text: I'll go round up Alice. [_sarcastically_] Another great party! [_She exits._]

speaker: Niles
text: I am so sorry.  I, uh, I don't know what got into me!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_indicating the empty beer cans_] I'd say about six of these. [_She cleans them up and goes into the kitchen._]

speaker: Niles
text: Everything was so perfect, and I just...blew it.  I, I... feel terrible.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, why don't you just go talk to him?

speaker: Niles
text: [_sadly_] I'm sure I am the last person he wants to see right now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I wouldn't be so sure about that.  He's not your hero for nothing.

speaker: Niles
text: [_agreeing_] Right.  Thank you, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: But maybe you should talk to him as Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, good idea.  [_Daphne re-enters.  Niles attempts to take off his wig, but it appears to be stuck._]

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, uh, help me get this wig off. [_He moves toward Frasier._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Right. [_He begins to pull off Niles's wig._]

speaker: Niles
text: Ow!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: Ow! [_slaps Frasier_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Ow!

speaker: Niles
text: [_louder_] OW! [_He fidgets and slaps Frasier again._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Ow! Stop it!

speaker: Niles
text: Ow! Ow!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right!  You put too much spirit gum on it.  You know, I'm going to need something to pry it off.  [_Doorbell rings._]

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll get it. [_handing Frasier a ladel_] Here, try this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thanks, Daphne.  All right now, come on, now, now hold still.

speaker: Niles
text: Easy, Easy.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.  [_Frasier begins to use the ladel to pry off the wig.  Daphne opens the door to reveal a group of kids, led by Justin, who has a bright and enthusiastic smile on his face._]

speaker: Kids
text: Trick or Treat!!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, how lovely!  One moment.  [_Daphne moves away, and the kids witness the following while Frasier is prying at Niles's head with the ladel._]

speaker: Niles
text: Wait, you're hurting me!

speaker: Frasier
text: That's because you keep fighting me!  [_Niles screams in pain and collapses to the ground as the wig is finally removed.  The kids, having thus seen "Old Man Crane" performing a painful "operation" on somebody's head, scream in terror and run away._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_still holding the wig_] No, children, come back!  I've got candy!!  [_Frasier runs out the door after the children, leaving us the view of Niles holding his head in pain.  Fade out._]
